column4: Q: how to make a folder go to TRASH after hitting DELETE key ? right now i deleted 2 folders using delete key .. they are not there in trash can ..  Q2: also, is there undelete util in ubuntu ?
Are those files hidden files? e.g. .file
nope .. not hidden .. basically movies i have seen .. i accidentally deleted one that i had not seen ..
As for your other question, there is no restore feature in ubuntu *yet*. From what I read, hardy may have this feature. As a side note, kubuntu already has the restore feature.
any possibility of changing the nautulus behaviour ? that when i hit delete, files shouldnt disappear totally, they should go to trash can ?
By default they should go to the trashbin. Double ckeck in Edit -> Prefences.
i havent ever gone in any prefes  ..  but will double check if u say
Is it files from your / partition or external hdd ?
there is one option under nautulus behaviour which says "include a delete command that bypasses trash"  .. its not checked .
the movie which accidentally got deleted was from NTFS windows partition
OK. Then the story is completely differnet. If you press delete fram a external fat or ntfs partitoin they are GONE!
okies, its then not a bug, but surely a warning message should pop up saying that the file will be gone and wont be moved to trash
where can i put such suggestion ?

Files on your local filesystem are stored in your ~/.Trash directory. If you have an external ext3 hdd, then pressing the delete key moves them to that drive's own .Trash folder. ntfs of course is not an officially supprted linux filesytem. I don't know about the other filesystems.
So my suggestion: use ext3. :)

i hope to :)
maybe that convinces you?

I held on to my external ntfs hdd for a while. But without the regular maintence tools required for ntfs, it eventually got fragmented beyond repair. So I just reformated to ext3. I'm happy now! :)
